solution.text:
Rate of flow : 3 \(\frac {litre}{min}\)
Initial Temp \(T_1\) = 19\(^\circ\)C
Final Temp \(T_2\) = 49\(^\circ\)C

\(\Delta T = T_2 - T_1 = 49 - 19 = 30^\circ C\)

Mass of water flowing through the pipe per min (m) = \(3 \frac {litre}{min} = 3000 \frac {g}{min}\)
Specific Heat of water (c) = 4.2 \(\frac {J}{g\;C}\)
Therefore, total heat required = \(\Delta Q = m \times c \times \Delta T = 3000 \times 4.2 \times 30\)
\(= 378000.0 \frac{J}{min}\)

Rate of gas required \(= \frac {378000.0}{5.7 \times 10^4} = 6.63 \frac {g}{min}\)

content.text: A water heater warms water flowing through a conductive pipe at the rate of 3 litres per minute from 19\(^\circ \)C to 49\(^ \circ \)C. The heater operates on a gas burner, with a heat of combustion of 5.7\( \times 10^4 \;\frac {J}{g}\). At what rate is the gas consumed?

solution.text:
Mass of Nitrogen \((m) = 9 kg = 9000\) g
Rise in Temperature \((\Delta T) = 15^ \circ C\)
Molecular Mass of \(N_2 (M) = \) 28 g
\(R = 8.3 \frac{J}{mol\;K}\)
Number of moles \((n) = \frac {m}{M} = \frac{9000}{28} = 321\)

\(C_p = \frac {7}{2} \times R = 29.05\)

\(\Delta Q = n \times C_p \times \Delta T = 321 \times 29.05 \times 15 = 140062.5\) J
The amount of heat that needs to be supplied : \(140062.5\) J

content.text: What amount of heat must be supplied to 9 kg of nitrogen at room temperature to raise its temperature by 15 \(^\circ\) C at constant pressure ? The molecular mass of \(N_2 = 28 g ; R = 8.3 \frac{J}{mol\;K} ; C_p = \frac {7}{2} \times R\)

solution.text:
For an isothermal reversible expansion of an ideal gas, the work done on the system by the surroundings is given by
\(w = - n \times R \times T \times ln (\frac {V2}{V1}) \)
We can use the relationship below from the ideal gas equation during an isothermal process to calculate \(\frac {V_2}{V_1}\):\(\frac{P_1}{P_2} = \frac{V_2}{V_1}\)
\(\implies \frac{V_2}{V_1} = \frac {2}{331} = 0.006\)

Now substitute the value in the equation for work:
\(w = - n \times R \times T \times ln (\frac {V2}{V1}) \)
\(w = - 2 \times 8.314 \times 355 \times ln (0.006) \)
\(w = - 2 \times 8.314 \times 355 \times ln (0.006) \)
\(w = 30.158 \;kJ\)

content.text: 2 moles of an ideal gas are compressed isothermally at 355 K from 2 atm to 331 atm. Calculate the work done on the system by the surroundings.(Calculate upto two decimal places)

solution.text:
Initial volume of the system (inside the cylinder) = \(V_1\)
Final volume of the system = \(V_2\)
Initial pressure of the system = \(P_1\)
Final pressure of the system = \(P_2\)
Ratio of specific heats \((\gamma)\) = 1.66

Since the process is adiabatic:
\(P_1 V_1^{\gamma} = P_2 V_2^{\gamma}\)
Final volume is reduced by a factor of 17. Therefore:
\(V_2 = \frac {V_1}{17}\)

\(\implies P_1 V_1^{\gamma} = P_2 (\frac {V_1}{17})^{\gamma}\)\(\implies \frac {P_2}{P_1} = \frac {V_1^{\gamma}}{(\frac {V_1}{17})^{\gamma}} = (17)^{\gamma} = (17)^{1.66} = 110.29\)

Hence, the pressure increases by a factor of 110.29.

content.text: A cylinder with a movable piston contains 8 moles of helium at standard temperature and pressure. The walls of the cylinder and the piston can be treated as adiabatic. By what factor does the pressure of the gas increase if the gas is compressed by a factor of 17? (Note that the ratio of specific heats for helium \((\gamma)\) = 1.66)

solution.text:
For the first, adiabatic process:
Net work done (W) = 16.3 J
Since it's an adiabatic process:
\(\Delta Q = 0 \implies \Delta W = -\;16.3\) J (Since the work is done on the system)

From the First Law of Thermodynamics: \(\Delta Q = \Delta U + \Delta W\)
\(\implies \Delta U = \Delta Q - \Delta W = - (- 16.3) = 16.3 \;J\)

In the second scenario the change in internal energy is the same since the state (B) is the same and the systems are identical.

The net heat absorbed \((\Delta Q)\) = 38.1 J
Therefore, \(\Delta W = \Delta Q - \Delta U\)\(\implies \Delta W = 38.1 - 16.3\)
\(\implies \Delta W = 21.8\) Joules

content.text: A system of Hydrogen gas is transformed adiabatically from an equilibrium state A to another equilibrium state B, requiring 16.3 J of work to be done on the system. An identical system is taken from state A to B via a different process in which the net heat absorbed by the system is 38.1 J. What is the work done by the system on the surroundings in the latter case ?

hint.text: The Zeroth Law states that when systems are in thermal equilibrium, they have the same temperature value. In which scenarios are the systems below in thermal equilibrium?

solution.text: In order for the systems to have the same temperature they must be in thermal equilibrium with each other. Adiabatic Walls are insulating and do not allow for the flow of heat, whereas Diathermic Walls and conducting and allow heat to flow between the adjacent systems until they are in equilibrium. content.text: In which of the following scenarios do the systems A, B and C have the same temperature at equilibrium given that \(T_A \neq T_B \neq T_C\) at \(time = 0\)?

solution.text:
The value of a state variable depends only on the particular state, not on the path used toarrive at that state. Based on that definition, we can characterize the following:
  • State variables : Pressure, Volume, Temperature, Internal Energy
  • Not state variables : Heat, Work,

content.text: Which of the following are following are thermodynamic state variables?

solution.text:
Intensive properties do not depend on the size of the system and remain the same if, for example, only half the system is considered. Therefore:
  • Intensive Properties : Pressure, Temperature, Density
  • Extensive Properties : Internal Energy, Volume, Mass

content.text: Which of the following are intensive properties?

solution.text: A process in which the temperature of the system is kept fixed throughout is called an isothermal process. For example : Expansion of gas in a cylinder placed in a large thermal reservoir at a fixed temperature.

content.text: A process in which the temperature of the system is kept fixed throughout is called an ____________ process.

solution.text: A process in which the volume of the system is kept fixed throughout is called an isochoric process. For example : An ideal Otto cycle where it is assumed that the burning of the gasoline-air mixture in an internal combustion engine car is instantaneous so temperature and pressure increase bu the volume remains the same.

content.text: A process in which the volume of the system is constant throughout is called an ____________ process.

solution.text: A process in which the pressure of the system is kept fixed throughout is called an isobaric process. For example : A weighted piston being lifted as the gas in the cylinder becomes hotter.

content.text: A process in which the pressure of the system is constant throughout is called an ____________ process.

solution.text: A process in which the system returns to its original state is called a cyclic process. For example : The Carnot Cycle as shown below

content.text: A process in which the system returns to its original state is called a ____________ process.

hint.text: The latent heat of water is 2256 \(\frac {J}{g}\). This means for 1 g of water \(\Delta\;Q = 2256 J\).

solution.text:
From the first law, we know that:
\(\Delta U = \Delta Q - P \Delta V\)
\(\Delta Q = 2256 J\)
\(P \Delta V = P \times (V_g - V_l) = 1.036 \times 10^5 \times (1633.9 - 1) \times 10^{-6} = 169.169\)
\(\implies \Delta U = 2256 - 169.169\)
\(\implies \Delta U = 2086.831 \;J\)

content.text: What is the change in internal energy for 1 gram of water to go from liquid to vapour phase at pressure of 1.036 bar. Note that the measured latent heat of water is 2256 \(\frac {J}{g}\). At the given pressure, 1 g of water has a volume \(1 \;cm^3\) in liquid phase and \(1633.9 \;cm^3\) in vapour phase.

solution.text:
Heat supplied to the system = - Heat removed from the system = - 127 Joules
Work done by the system on the surroundings = - Work done by the surroundings on the system = - 90 Joules

Therefore, from the First Law of Thermodynamics: \(\Delta U = \Delta Q - \Delta W\)
\(\implies \Delta U = - 127 - (- 90)\)
\(\implies \Delta U = (-37)\) Joules

content.text:
Change in Internal Energy \((\Delta U) = \Delta Q - \Delta W\)
\(=\) \(0\) Joules \(-\) \(0\) Joules
\(=\) \(0\) Joules

\(\Delta Q\) = Heat supplied to the system by the surroundings
\(\Delta W\) = Work done by the system on the surroundings









You can use the widget above to influence the system (Use the slider to change the heat supplied and use the arrows to move the piston). Based on the calculations above, what is the change in internal energy if 127 Joules of heat is removed from the system and 90 Joules of work is done on the system by the surroundings?
